abstracts.cdata!:
The project's objectives were
            amended to be defined more narrowly and specifically, and
            against these objectives the project did achieve some
            notable outputs: thus the project outcome was satisfactory,
            and project sustainability is considered on the whole,
            likely. Despite the weaknesses of the project at entry,
            because of the Bank's efforts to address difficult
            issues in an innovative fashion, and the satisfactory
            performance during supervision, the Bank's overall
            performance is rated satisfactory. Overall Borrower
            performance was unsatisfactory. Lessons learned include the
            following: Capacity constraints in Mozambique are severe;
            the Bank should therefore guard against overestimating
            Borrower capacity to implement by making implementation
            arrangements simple and objectives and outputs practical.
            Where coordination and leadership in the Government and the
            implementing agencies is weak, managers at the technical
            level are unlikely to commit themselves to a project beyond
            its use in supporting activities in which they are already
            engaged. Capacity building projects should be designed
            within a framework of long-term Bank commitment (such as is
            now possible with an APL). Where implementation capacity is
            especially scarce, projects should ensure that local staff
            have needed skills, and that dedicated personnel for the
            project are identified and mbilized. Post-war reconstruction
            projects should distinguish between emergency activities and
            activities leading to long-term reform.
